John McCain had his most effective night at taking the fight to Barack Obama, pushing him harder, looking at him, being more interactive with him, and bringing up some of the subjects that he has been pressed to bring up by some of his own core supporters.

The William Ayers connection or Ledge (ph) connection, the Acorn matter, Fannie and Freddie, some of the things that Republicans are upset about in this fall, this autumn of angst and unhappiness in America.

He smiled.
He even chuckled a few times.
He parried the thrusts from John McCain, including the personal ones, and he seemed to emerge at the end of the night pretty comfortable with his own skin and his own lead.

There's much being made of their body language and their facial expressions.
What did you see when you watched this?
Part of the problem, of course, is what you see on television is not exactly what's happening on stage.

What you see on television is often the result of either a one shot, where they show you one of the two men without the other, and you don't really have a sense of how close anyone else might be to him.
And then there is the two shot, the split screen, where you can actually watch the reactions on the faces of the candidate who isn't speaking.
And that is a fairly interesting and sometimes devastating way to watch a debate.

I think everyone recalls who saw the 2000 debates between George Bush and Al Gore that, if you listened on radio or watched strictly the one shots, you got one impression, but if you saw the split screen, you saw Al Gore rolling his eyes and looking heavenward and making a lot of other gestures that people thought were disrespectful and maybe a little bush league.
That hurt in that particular case Al Gore more than it hurt George Bush.

So in the debate last night, a lot of the two shots - a lot of those split screens showed John McCain looking angry, showed him looking very irritated, showed him looking upset and staring over at what appeared to be the next head just inches away, even though the two were seated on opposite sides of a rather large table.
